displayed_text: Patient: Oh my God! Doctor: It’s down. You’re down to three point seven. Patient: And that was when? Doctor: Today. Patient: No kidding? Doctor: No kidding. One dose of chemo. (Yells) Patient: That gives me goose bumps. They never show up because my skin’s changed. Doctor: Yeah so here you go. (Laughs) Patient: Alright I’m gonna shut up and just let you keep talking. Doctor: Yeah well you know you need more chemo. That’s really what you need (laughs) Patient: I do? Doctor: You do. How ‘bout that. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation? Doctor: So we actually prefer it because we actually know how to treat your whole body systemically with all these medicines from the chemist. (whistle noise) Patient: Right. Doctor: With these medicines, but we also, and it also gives you more time to heal. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: From the surgery, which is better for you as far as long-term side effects. Family Member: Uh hum. Okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So we do it in this order for everybody. Patient: Okay. Is the castration, the two years, I understand that is standard care. Are there ever any times when that is shortened or – I understand in my case that is likely two years – I accept that that’s what it’s going to be. Doctor: Okay, okay. Family Member: Is that even in case number three, though, the aggressive with the chemo and the super hormone, or is the hormone; I just want to ask In standard care two you said the hormone shot would be for two years. In the third option with the chemo, how long is that going to be last? Doctor: So the way we’re doing it, it’s still two years.

Patient: As long as I’m feeling up to it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. We can fill one of those papers out. Yeah. Patient: Okay. What else did I have? Doctor: If you need to go upstairs, you can. Patient: You can go up and take care of it. Doctor: You’ve got to take care of business. Go ahead. You know we’ll be here a while. (Laughs) Family Member: I may have to go sign an order. Doctor: He wrote down the questions? That’s pretty good. Family Member: Well, yeah. I mean, I am his daughter. (Laughs) Doctor: Does that mean it’s going to execute. I mean. Patient: I’m not as thorough as she is about things. My notes are really basic. Patient: Okay. What are some of the things that I should really be on the lookout for, the fatigue? Doctor: I think really just the tiredness. If you feel like you’re more off balance, you know, let’s say it’s weeks from now, that’s something also that’s pretty subtle that can come up just like that (snaps)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But most of the things we'll be measuring will be that area by your bladder that was squishing the kidney. So that's a big spot that we really want to keep an eye on. Then of course, bone stuff, but that's an area and you’d want to know that this stuff is shrinking. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Chemo is chemo. So, you know, like we talked about last time, whether it's the pill version or the IV, we always worry about hair loss, you know, tiredness, how it affects your liver numbers, that's measured by blood. We always worry about your white cells, red cells, platelets- Patient: Right, right. Doctor: -you know, all the words that make you you. But that's why you're here getting, you know= Family Member 1: Monitored. Doctor: Yeah, monitored. And if it's the worst thing you've ever done, stop, start over on something else. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: If you feel fine, and you continue, then thumbs up. So it's a work in progress, really, for all of us. But I think if we just keep communicating, we'll do right by you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, so my next step, honestly, is to get M____ in here so that we can just get the timing and things right and logistics. Family Member 1: So we're not starting nothing today.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t combine Zytiga and the radium together. I specifically say that because there have been patients who have had leftover pills and yeah. Hey, the things going up after I try the pill. But actually, when they combined it people did worse so that study has already been done and people got more bone fractures so that’s no fun. So, I just tell everybody, you know, you’ve had it before. You can go on it after but not at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s actually an absolute no-go black box. Okay, good. Family Member: What does the PSA going up, what does it, is it gonna cause it to spread? Doctor: It might really. No. But it might, again it’s not a reflection of what’s happening. It’s almost like oh, the ship’s sinking and the rats are all kind of jumping off. I’ve had patients that go from twenty to one hundred to five hundred and you’re like, oh, but they actually feel better. So, like it doesn’t match you. Family Member: It’s not the biggest thing because people always ask you what’s your PSA. Doctor: Yeah, no, just say oh, I’m on a treatment where the PSA actually goes up and like, you know, we have a vaccine therapy that that happens but Xofigo for sure and we know that because actually one of the fellows who is now faculty wrote a paper on our collective experience when we first started doing it and Patient: Alright. I have something to run by you Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: with me going out of town and taking this. Would I be alright to travel? Doctor: Yeah. So, the good news is that we figured out that you will leave with a piece of paper after the radiation doctor gives you the injection because you will set off the TSA sensors.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: anymore. Which… Patient: Just a second, even with the BET1? Doctor: No. For the BET1 that study will then kick in you’ll be registered to that study and they will give you from that study they will give you the Xtandi and the BET medication. Patient: Because ten thousand dollars a month is not something… Doctor: Well that’s okay. We can find ways around it and getting it covered if we need to. But chances are if you were to go on standard treatment, then yeah we’d have to wait and see what your insurance pays. Sorry about that. Family Member: That’s okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So um I think we should take it one step at a time and keep all our options open. So uh stay with the Xtandi and the Lupron and bring in the BET. And uh I I’m gonna be getting it from Midtown rather from here and they’ll know that? Doctor: Oh well once – what I was going to propose is that I give you the copy of the consent. If you want you can read it and uh if you’re ready to sign today you can, or we can schedule all the testing in anticipation of putting you on the study and all of that downtown and then that same day you can come in and sign the consent and do all the testing necessary. That gives you some time to think it over talk it over before signing. Patient: And you said it would just be a couple days I’d have to be there? Doctor: The two days are the long days. There are other days that you would be coming in and I just… Patient: For how long?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which why I told J___ let’s give it another whirl before you know you get too… Patient: Yeah absolutely. Doctor: …pooped out from the Taxotere. So I got M_____ on it. I’m just trying to look at your ankles over there. Just swelling more or what’s? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh, it’s just your socks. Okay. Patient: Just socks. She was checking I think for swelling. Doctor: Yeah. She’s pretty good. Patient: In fact I think um Doctor: Okay Patient: Dr. S____ put me on um oh what is it? It’s a, it must be a diuretic, but it’s I can tell you… Doctor: Mmm. Oh hydrochlorothiazide or Lasix? Patient: It’s not a Lasix or at least I don’t know (sound of zipper)

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes longer than that. Family Member: Okay. Patient: At which point we’ll be transitioning to a different kind of treatment, hopefully. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And, that’s the next discussion, what that is. And, that, that’s evolving, particularly for guys with your story. Family Member: Okay, so then you’re looking at like, like combinations of drugs? Doctor: Yeah. Normally, we would keep you on the hormone -- forever at that point, unfortunately. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then, add things to them. Standardly, we would add another hormone, so you’d be on two. Research-wise, we would potentially consider these other drugs, particularly because of your mutation. Family Member: So, no chemo then? Doctor: No, not in, not in the short term.

Family Member: So a donut sends your sugar up to three hundred. So you know that. Doctor: Everything else is good. Patient: So does Raisin Bran Doctor: Okay. So, I will see you in April. Hopefully, not sooner, if anyone in your family has questions about this, you can direct them to me, and I can potentially hook them up with--- Family Member: Do you have, uh, a nurse that helps you do this stuff or do we just – Doctor: Ehhh. Just call me, and I will find somebody. Family Member: Just you? Oh wow. Doctor: And, if you want to know more, I mean, we can also have you, an appointment with one of our genetic counselors. Patient: Well, you, you gave me a card with your other e-mail. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Not – so I still have that. Doctor: Yeah, so if anybody, you know, has questions about it and wants more information. You know, I’m not a genetic counselor, but I can at least tell them what I just told you

Patient: You know I’m not trying to underestimate anything you know and you know because I never felt you know from the beginning I never felt… Doctor: Felt any symptoms. Patient: Yes. You know. Doctor: I understand. Neither did I. So we’ll get you to see Dr. R____ as soon as possible and I’ll see you back in three months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you get your blood test before you come back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Sound good? Patient: Thank you again. Doctor: Tell them before the end of July because I’m taking off June and July I’m having hip surgery. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So I’ll be seeing you though towards the end of July. Okay?

Patient: Yeah. I feel good. Doctor: I just, uh, that is frustrating. I was hoping they would do something to help. Patient: Well, I can always go somewhere else, but you know how that goes. Doctor: Reduce the pressure. Yeah, I wonder if we should have you do that? Patient: It’s, it’s a pain. You know? You know? Why don’t I do that? Doctor: I was wondering if we should get you an appointment with somebody else. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. I was thinking to go down Y___. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. You can go there, definitely. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or, you know, at SM___’s, there is a neurosurgeon who’s very good. Family Member: Now, does he ever see, does he have-? Patient: SM___’s, where? Doctor: Here, L___, so, like a few miles from here.

Healthcare Professional: Like the timing? Of the course -- Patient: No, the, eh, um. The aches and pains, I got a bunch of them. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Patient: Just, more -- But like the ridges on the nailbeds. ‘Cuz if I, if I notice something that is abnormal and say, “MMmmm.” I’m gonna make a phone call. But that’s gonna just doesn’t make sense. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. In your consent, it has adverse things to expect, what are more common, what are less common. It’s in your consent. Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: So, it’s in there. I’m supposed to go over it with ya. You know, then you have people like T_, myself, C_ as resources, to just say, “Hey, you know, my nails - It could be that every time I’m getting chemo, things stop growing.” And then once the chemo is out of your body, it starts growing, so you’re gonna get ridges. Family Member: Ohhh. Doctor: So, you can sorta like. Doctor: Exactly. So, you’ll sorta know those sorts of things. Family Member: Wow.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Terrific. Thank you. Doctor: So I’ll just let you know what the options are. Patient: Thank you. Appreciate it. Doctor: Alright? Patient: Alright. Doctor: Well thank you both for participating. I think you know I think we’ve very appreciative that you know- Patient: Well I hope we learned, we learned something. Maybe. Maybe not. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s a crazy thing to try. So you know it’s not the typical patient that says yeah, I’m, I’m fine. I really appreciate your involvement. Hopefully we’ve got a lot more stuff we can do here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: If you, if you go with (game one) Doctor: Okay. Well, I’m guessing you had a- Patient: We had, we had to get up at five-thirty in the morning to go on the safari because that’s when the animals are most active. Yeah. So that was- Doctor: So what did you see? Like what animals did you see? Patient: Oh, we saw, we saw the five big ones. Doctor: Oh, really? Patient: Yeah. The elephant, giraffe, lions. Doctor: And where did you go? What like park or what was? Family Member: Kruger National Park. Patient: Kruger. Doctor: Kruger. Yeah. I’ve heard about that. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. I just need somebody to send me like ah- Doctor: Huh? Patient: Can you get somebody to send me like five thousand dollars? Doctor: To what? Doctor: Hum, but, then, you guys tell us, but we should make a decision one way or the other. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I’m going to give you those side effect sheets. Family Member: Yes. Please. Doctor: We’ll start there. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay.
